div.p: This element can be found in expressed, tagg it as WRITING . Belonging conceptually to TextualFeatures, captures general and relevant information and comment about those fictional characters who populate an author's work. It contains at least a full statement. It often contains the ancillary elements TCHARACTERTTYPE/ROLE or TCHARACTERNAME, but it has no mandatory or optional sub-elements or attributes.

div.codeblock: <TCHARACTERIZATION>MG cites the psychopathic Bruno as exemplifying the way that, as a novelist, she is able to love even her repellent characters.</TCHARACTERIZATION>

<TCHARACTERIZATION>These people in the present day, of varied ethnicity, class status, and personal ideology (whose incompatible inner worlds make up the story), are all affected in various, unquantifable ways by the now long-past British Empire; they live in the shadow of its decline</TCHARACTERIZATION>
<TCHARACTERIZATION>Elizabeth Pipe Wolferstan's fairy tales feature several delightful fairies. </TCHARACTERIZATION>

div.p: Use for general statements about the fictional characters in a writerâ€™s oeuvre or particular work, rather than describing a particular individual. Often used to flag the use of actual models in fiction. If you want to write about one particular character's role, see TCHARACTERNAME.
